overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnic, amend and establish various definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, and incorporate fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [12] The measure amends multiple definitions and penalties for fireworks offenses, including establishing heightened penalties if another person suffers substantial bodily injury, serious bodily injury, or death as a result of the fireworks offenses. [12] It also adds fireworks infractions to the existing adjudication of infractions process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [12]
appropriations: The Conference Committee amended this measure by deleting the appropriation. [13] A prior version of the measure included a purpose to appropriate funds, but this was removed. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: The legislature assumes that a more robust continuum of enforcement mechanisms must be established to promote compliance with the fireworks control laws. [12] The fireworks infractions system is assumed to allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases, while also allowing them to prioritize higher-level cases as appropriate. [12] For offenses resulting in injury or death, the bill assumes a person shall be strictly liable with respect to the result that the aerial devices, articles pyrotechnic, or display fireworks caused the injury or death. [12]
agency_impact: The fireworks infractions system will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases. [12] This will also allow them to prioritize higher-level cases as appropriate. [12] The system is intended to allow judicial, prosecutorial, and law enforcement resources to be used more efficiently and effectively. [12]
economic_impact: The legislature finds that illegal fireworks result in fires, serious burn injuries, and fatalities. [12] Increased fireworks-related calls heavily strain public safety agencies, which adds to the cost of state and county resources. [12] Improved enforcement of fireworks control laws is necessary to protect property from avoidable fire damage and protect the community from fire- and explosion-related injuries. [12]
policy_impact: The purpose of this Act is to establish various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnic. [12] The measure incorporates fireworks infractions into the existing adjudication process for traffic and emergency period infractions. [12] This policy includes implementing graduated penalties for repeat or felony-level offenses and imposing enhanced penalties for offenses that result in injury or death. [12]
revenue_sources: Revenue will be generated from permit fees, including a $25 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fee for consumer fireworks like firecrackers and a $110 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fee for aerial devices or display fireworks. [12] Fines will also be a source of revenue, such as a $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for purchasing or possessing consumer fireworks without a permit. [12] In addition, the court will impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction where judgment is entered for the State, with fees deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [12]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill establishes several new fines and fees. [12] A person who purchases or possesses consumer fireworks without a permit shall be subject to a $200 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] Distributing consumer fireworks outside of the allowed time period is subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] Carriers shipping fireworks who fail to notify officials are subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a first offense, a $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a second offense, and a $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine for a third or subsequent offense. [12] Possessing aerial devices or display fireworks where the weight cannot be determined will result in a $300 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) fine. [12] Other violations of the chapter are subject to a fine between $500 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) and $5,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt). [12] Obstructing an inspector is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of no more than $2,000 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt). [12] Permit fees are established at $25 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for firecrackers and $110 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for aerial devices. [12] An administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [12] Of the fines collected for violations, twenty per cent will be paid to the State and eighty per cent to the county for law enforcement purposes. [12]
